Bobcat (Lion).1: Get to know the members of your den.
Bobcat (Lion).2: Have your Lion adult partner or den leader read the Scout Law to you. Demonstrate your understanding of being friendly.
Bobcat (Lion).3: Share with your Lion adult partner, during a den meeting or at home, a time when you have demonstrated the Cub Scout motto 'Do Your Best.'
Bobcat (Lion).4: At home, with your parent or legal guardian, do the activities in the booklet 'How to Protect Your Children from Child Abuse: A Parent’s Guide.'

Fun on the Run.1: Identify the five different food groups.
Fun on the Run.2: Practice hand washing. Point out when you should wash your hands.
Fun on the Run.4: Practice methods that help you rest.

Lion's Roar.1: With permission from your parent or legal guardian watch the Protect Yourself Rules video for the Lion rank.
Lion's Roar.2: With your Lion adult partner, demonstrate Shout, Run, Tell as explained in the Protect Yourself Rules video.
Lion's Roar.3: With your Lion adult partner, demonstrate how to access emergency services.
Lion's Roar.4: With your Lion adult partner, demonstrate how to safely cross a street or walk in a parking lot.

Lion's Pride.1: With your parent or legal guardian talk about your family’s faith traditions. Draw a picture of your favorite family’s faith tradition holiday or celebration.
Lion's Pride.2: With your family, attend a religious service OR other gathering that shows how your family expresses Family & Reverence.
Lion's Pride.3: Make a cheerful card or a drawing for someone you love and give it to them.

King of the Jungle.1: Draw a picture or take a photo of the people you live with.
King of the Jungle.2: With your Lion adult partner, choose a job that will help your family. Follow through by doing that job at least once.
King of the Jungle.3: Talk with a grandparent or other older adult about what citizenship means to them.

Mountain Lion.1: Identify the Cub Scout Six Essentials. Show what you do with each item.
Mountain Lion.2: With your den, pack, or family, take a walk outside spending for at least 20 minutes exploring the outdoors with your Cub Scout Six Essentials.  While outside, identify things that you see with your Lion adult partner that are natural and things that are manmade.
Mountain Lion.4: Identify common animals that are found where you live.  Separate those animals into domesticated and wild.

Lion Elective Adventure.1: Choose and complete any Lion elective adventure

Lion Elective Adventure 2.1: Choose and complete any Lion elective adventure

Bobcat (Tiger).1: Get to know the members of your den.
Bobcat (Tiger).2: Recite the Scout Oath with your den, including your Tiger adult partner.
Bobcat (Tiger).3: Have your Tiger adult partner or den leader read the Scout Law to you.  Demonstrate your understanding of being trustworthy, helpful, or friendly.
Bobcat (Tiger).4: Demonstrate the Cub Scout sign, Cub Scout salute and Cub Scout handshake.  Show how each are used.
Bobcat (Tiger).5: Share with your Tiger adult partner, at a den meeting or at home, a time when you have demonstrated the Cub Scout motto 'Do Your Best.'
Bobcat (Tiger).6: At home, with your parent or legal guardian, do the activities in the booklet 'How to Protect Your Children from Child Abuse: A Parent’s Guide.'

Tiger Bites.2: Practice hand washing. Point out when you should wash your hands.
Tiger Bites.4: Practice methods that help you sleep.

Tiger's Roar.1: With permission from your parent or legal guardian watch the Protect Yourself Rules video for the Tiger rank.
Tiger's Roar.2: With your Tiger adult partner, demonstrate Shout, Run, Tell as explained in the Protect Yourself Rules video.
Tiger's Roar.3: With your Tiger adult partner, demonstrate how to access emergency services.
Tiger's Roar.4: With your Tiger adult partner, demonstrate that you know what to do if you get lost or separated.

Tiger Circles.1: With your parent or legal guardian talk about your family’s faith traditions.   Identify three holidays or celebrations that are part of your family’s faith traditions. Draw a picture of your favorite family’s faith tradition holiday or celebration.
Tiger Circles.2: With your family, attend a religious service OR other gathering that shows how your family expresses Family & Reverence.
Tiger Circles.3: Carry out an act of kindness.

Team Tiger.1: Play a game with your den, or family members, that has a set of rules.  Discuss why rules are important to the game you are playing.
Team Tiger.2: With your Tiger Adult Partner, choose a job that will help your team. Follow through by doing that job at least once.
Team Tiger.3: Play a game that requires at least 2 teams with your den, or two other family members. Afterwards discuss what it means to be part of a team and what makes a good team member.

Tigers in the Wild.1: Identify the Cub Scout Six Essentials.  Show what you do with each item.
Tigers in the Wild.2: With your den leader or Tiger adult partner, learn about the Outdoor Code.
Tigers in the Wild.3: With your den, pack, or family, take a walk outside spending for at least 20 minutes exploring the outdoors with your Cub Scout Six Essentials.  While outside, identify things that you see with your Tiger adult partner that are natural and things that are manmade.
Tigers in the Wild.4: Identify common animals that are found where you live. Learn which of those animals is domesticated and which animal is wild.  Draw a picture of your favorite animal.
Tigers in the Wild.5: Look for a tree where you live.  Describe how this tree is helpful.

Tiger Elective Adventure.1: Choose and complete any Tiger elective adventure

Tiger Elective Adventure 2.1: Choose and complete any Tiger elective adventure

Bobcat (Wolf).1: Get to know members of your den.
Bobcat (Wolf).2: Recite the Scout Oath and the Scout Law with your den and den leader.
Bobcat (Wolf).4: With your den create a den Code of Conduct.
Bobcat (Wolf).5: Demonstrate the Cub Scout sign, Cub Scout salute and Cub Scout handshake. Show how each is used.
Bobcat (Wolf).6: Share with your den, or family, a time when you demonstrated the Cub Scout motto 'Do Your Best.'
Bobcat (Wolf).7: At home, with your parent or legal guardian, do the activities in the booklet 'How to Protect Your Children from Child Abuse: A Parent’s Guide.'

Running With the Pack.1: Sample 3 different foods that are naturally 3 different colors.  The food must be a protein, vegetable, fruit, dairy, or a grain.
Running With the Pack.2: Demonstrate the proper way to brush your teeth.
Running With the Pack.3: Be active for 30 minutes with your den or at least 1 other person that includes both stretching and moving.
Running With the Pack.4: Be active for 10 minutes doing personal exercises.
Running With the Pack.5: Do a relaxing activity for 10 minutes.
Running With the Pack.6: Review your Scouting America Annual Health and Medical record with your parent or guardian. Discuss your ability to participate in den and pack activities.

Safety in Numbers.1: With permission from your parent or legal guardian, watch the 'Protect Yourself Rules video for the Wolf rank.
Safety in Numbers.2: Discuss 'safe touch' as seen in the Protect Yourself Rules video.
Safety in Numbers.3: Learn about the buddy system and demonstrate how it works.
Safety in Numbers.4: Review common safety rules and demonstrate the proper use of playground equipment.

Footsteps.1: With your parent or legal guardian talk about your family’s faith traditions.   Identify three holidays or celebrations that are part of your family’s faith traditions. Make a craft or work of art of your favorite family’s faith tradition holiday or celebration.
Footsteps.2: With your family, attend a religious service OR other gathering that shows how your family expresses reverence.
Footsteps.3: Carry out an act of kindness.
Footsteps.4: Listen to or read Aesop’s fable 'The Boy Who Cried Wolf.' With your den or family discuss why being truthful is important.

Council Fire.1: Learn how to properly care for and fold the United States flag. With your den or pack, participate in a flag ceremony.
Council Fire.2: Identify three points of the Scout Law that are important to being a good neighbor.
Council Fire.3: Build a model of your home.
Council Fire.4: Using the same materials from requirement 3, create a model of a building in your community.
Council Fire.5: Using the models built in requirements 3 and 4, create a neighborhood.
Council Fire.6: Participate in a service project.  Explain how your volunteering is helpful to your neighborhood.

Paws on the Path.1: Identify the Cub Scout Six Essentials.  Show what you do with each item.
Paws on the Path.2: Learn about the buddy system and how it works in the outdoors. Pick a buddy for your walk.
Paws on the Path.3: Identify appropriate clothes and shoes for your walk outside.  Do your best to wear them on your walk.
Paws on the Path.4: Learn about the Outdoor Code and Leave No Trace Principle for Kids.
Paws on the Path.5: With your den, pack, or family, take a walk outside for at least 30 minutes to explore nature in your surroundings. Describe four different animals, domestic or wild, that you could see on your walk.

Wolf Elective Adventure.1: Choose and complete any Wolf elective adventure

Wolf Elective Adventure 2.1: Choose and complete any Wolf elective adventure

Bobcat (Bear).1: Get to know members of your den.
Bobcat (Bear).2: Recite the Scout Oath and Law with your den and den leader.
Bobcat (Bear).3: Learn about the Scout Oath. Identify the three points of the Scout Oath.
Bobcat (Bear).4: With your den create a den Code of Conduct.
Bobcat (Bear).5: Learn about the denner position and responsibilities.
Bobcat (Bear).6: Demonstrate the Cub Scout sign, Cub Scout salute, and Cub Scout handshake.  Show how each is used.
Bobcat (Bear).7: Share with your den, or family, a time when you demonstrated the Cub Scout motto 'Do Your Best.' Explain why it is important to do your best.
Bobcat (Bear).8: At home, with your parent or legal guardian, do the activities in the booklet 'How to Protect Your Children from Child Abuse: A Parent’s Guide.'

Bear Strong.1: Sample food from three of the following food groups: protein, vegetables, fruits, dairy, and grains.
Bear Strong.2: Be active for 30 minutes with your den or at least one other person that includes both stretching and moving.
Bear Strong.3: Be active for 15 minutes doing personal exercises that include cardio, muscular strength, and flexibility.
Bear Strong.4: Do a relaxing activity for 10 minutes.
Bear Strong.5: Review your Scouting America Annual Health and Medical record with your parent or guardian. Discuss your ability to participate in den and pack activities.

Standing Tall.1: With permission from your parent or legal guardian, watch the Protect Yourself Rules video for the Bear rank.
Standing Tall.2: Complete the Personal Space Bubble worksheet that is part of the Protect Yourself Rules resources.
Standing Tall.3: With your parent or legal guardian, set up a family policy for digital devices.
Standing Tall.4: Identify common personal safety gear for your head, eyes, mouth, hands, and feet.  List how each of these items protect you.  Demonstrate the proper use of personal safety gear for an activity.

Fellowship.1: With your parent or legal guardian talk about your family’s faith traditions. Identify three holidays or celebrations that are part of your family’s faith traditions. Make a craft,  work of art, or a food item that is part  of your favorite family’s faith tradition, holiday or celebration.
Fellowship.2: With your family, attend a religious service OR other gathering that shows how your family expresses reverence.
Fellowship.3: Carry out an act of kindness.
Fellowship.4: With your parent or legal guardian identify a religion or faith that is different from your own.  Determine two things that it has in common with your family’s beliefs.

Paws for Action.1: Familiarize yourself with the flag of the United States of America including the history, demonstrating how to raise and lower the flag, how to properly fold and display, and the United States etiquette.
Paws for Action.2: Identify 3 symbols that represent the United States. Pick your favorite and make a model, work of art, or other craft that depicts the symbol.
Paws for Action.3: Learn about the mission of any non-profit.  Find out how they fund their activities and how volunteers are used to help.

Bear Habitat.1: Prepare for a one-mile walk by gathering the Cub Scout Six Essentials and weather appropriate clothing and shoes.
Bear Habitat.2: Know Before You Go - Identify the location of your walk on a map and confirm your one-mile route.
Bear Habitat.3: Choose the Right Path - Learn about the path and surrounding area you will be walking on.
Bear Habitat.4: Trash your Trash - Make a plan for what you will do with your personal trash or trash you find along the trail.
Bear Habitat.5: Leave What You Find - Take pictures along your walk or bring a sketchbook to draw five things that you want to remember on your walk.
Bear Habitat.6: Be Careful with Fire - Determine the fire danger rating along your path.
Bear Habitat.7: Respect Wildlife - From a safe distance, identify as you look up, down, and around you, six signs of any mammals, birds, insects, reptiles.
Bear Habitat.8: Be Kind to Other Visitors - Identify what you need to do as a den to be kind to others on the path.
Bear Habitat.9: Go on your one-mile walk while practicing your Leave No Trace Principles for Kids.

Bear Elective Adventure.1: Choose and complete any Bear elective adventure

Bear Elective Adventure 2.1: Choose and complete any Bear elective adventure

Bobcat (Webelos).1: Get to know members of your den.
Bobcat (Webelos).2: Recite the Scout Oath and the Scout Law with your den and den leader.  Describe the three points of the Scout Oath
Bobcat (Webelos).4: With your den create a den Code of Conduct.
Bobcat (Webelos).5: Learn about the denner position and responsibilities.
Bobcat (Webelos).6: Demonstrate the Cub Scout sign, Cub Scout salute and Cub Scout handshake.  Show how each is used.
Bobcat (Webelos).7: At home, with your parent or legal guardian do the activities in the booklet 'How to Protect Your Children from Child Abuse: A Parent's Guide.'

Stronger, Faster, Higher.1: With your den or family, plan, cook, and eat a balanced meal.
Stronger, Faster, Higher.2: Be active for 30 minutes with your den or at least one other person in a way that includes both stretching and moving.
Stronger, Faster, Higher.3: Be active for 15 minutes doing personal exercises that boost your heart rate, use your muscles, and work on flexibility.
Stronger, Faster, Higher.4: Do a relaxing activity for 10 minutes
Stronger, Faster, Higher.5: Review your Scouting America Annual Health and Medical Record with your parent or legal guardian. Discuss your ability to participate in den and pack activities.

My Safety.1: With permission from your parent or legal guardian, watch the Protect Yourself Rules video for the Webelos rank.
My Safety.2: Identify items in your house that are hazardous and make sure they are stored properly.  Identify on the package where it describes what to do if someone is accidentally exposed to them.
My Safety.3: Identify ways you and your family keep your home or your meeting space safe.
My Safety.4: Complete the Be Prepared for Natural Events worksheet. Complete a worksheet for at least two natural events most likely to happen near where you live.

My Family.1: With your parent or legal guardian, talk about your family's faith traditions.   Identify three holidays or celebrations that are part of your family's faith traditions. Make a craft, work of art, or a food item that is part of your family's faith traditions.
My Family.2: Carry out an act of kindness.
My Family.3: With your parent or legal guardian identify a religion or faith that is different from your own.  Identify two things that it has in common with your family's beliefs.
My Family.4: Discuss with our parent or legal guardian what it means to be reverent.  Tell how you practice being reverent in your daily life.

My Community.1: Learn about majority and plurality types of voting.
My Community.2: Speak with someone who is elected to their position.  Discover the type of voting that was used for to elect them and why.
My Community.3: Choose a federal law and create a timeline of the history of the law.  Include the involvement of the 3 branches of government.

Webelos Walkabout.1: Prepare for a 2-mile walk outside. Gather your Cub Scout Six Essentials and weather appropriate clothing and shoes.
Webelos Walkabout.2: Plan a 2-mile route for your walk.
Webelos Walkabout.3: Check the weather forecast for the time of your planned 2-mile walk.
Webelos Walkabout.4: Review the four points of Scouting America SAFE Checklist and how you will apply them on your 2-mile walk.
Webelos Walkabout.5: Demonstrate first aid for each of the following events that could occur on your 2-mile walk: blister, sprained ankle, sunburn, dehydration and heat related illness.
Webelos Walkabout.6: With your den, pack, or family, go on your 2-mile walk while practicing the Leave No Trace Principles for Kids and Outdoor Code.
Webelos Walkabout.7: After your 2-mile walk, discuss with your den what went well and what you would do differently next time.

Webelos Elective Adventure.1: Choose and complete any Webelos elective adventure

Webelos Elective Adventure 2.1: Choose and complete another Webelos elective adventure

Bobcat (AOL).1: Demonstrate the patrol method by choosing a patrol name and electing a patrol leader. Discuss the benefits of using the patrol method.
Bobcat (AOL).2: Get to know members of your patrol.
Bobcat (AOL).3: Recite the Scout Oath and Scout Law with your patrol.
Bobcat (AOL).4: With your patrol create a Code of Conduct.
Bobcat (AOL).5: Demonstrate the Scout sign, Scout salute and Scout handshake used by Scouting America.  Show how each are used.
Bobcat (AOL).6: Learn the Scouting America slogan and motto.
Bobcat (AOL).7: With your patrol, or with your parent/legal guardian, visit a Scouting America troop.
Bobcat (AOL).8: At home, with your parent or legal guardian, do the activities in the booklet 'How to Protect Your Children from Child Abuse: A Parent’s Guide.'

Personal Fitness.1: Plan a balanced meal that you would eat when camping.  Prepare that meal using the gear you would use on a campout.
Personal Fitness.2: Examine what it is to be  physically fit and how you incorporate this in your life.  Track the number of times you are active for 30 minutes or longer over a 14-day period. Share with your patrol or family what you enjoyed and if you feel you are living up to the Scout Oath of being physically strong.
Personal Fitness.3: Be active for 30 minutes with your patrol, a younger den, or at least one other person in a way that includes both stretching and moving.
Personal Fitness.4: Review your Scouting America Annual Health and Medical Record with your parent or legal guardian. Discuss your ability to participate in Arrow of Light patrol and pack activities.

First Aid.1: With permission from your parent or legal guardian, watch the Protect Yourself Rules video for the Arrow of Light rank.
First Aid.2: Explain what you should do if you encounter someone in need of first aid.
First Aid.3: Demonstrate what to do for hurry cases of first aid: serious bleeding, heart attack or sudden cardiac arrest, stopped breathing, stroke, poisoning.
First Aid.4: Demonstrate how to help a choking victim.
First Aid.6: Demonstrate how to treat the following: cuts and scratches, burns and scalds, bites and stings of insects and animals, and nosebleed.
First Aid.7: Make a personal first-aid kit. Demonstrate the proper use of each item in your first-aid kit.

Duty to God.1: Discuss with your parent or legal guardian your family’s faith traditions or one of your choosing. Choose a view or value of that faith tradition that is related to the Scout Law. Discuss with your family how each family member demonstrates this value.
Duty to God.2: Meet with a representative of a faith-based organization in your local community who provides a service that assists people in crisis regardless of their faith. Identify who they help and how.
Duty to God.3: Discuss with your parent, legal guardian, or an adult leader what 'Duty to God' means to you. Tell how you practice your Duty to God in your daily life.

Citizenship.1: Identify a community service project that your patrol or pack could accomplish.  Use Scouting America’s SAFE Checklist and develop a plan to conduct the service project safely.
Citizenship.2: Participate in a service project for a minimum of two hours or multiple service projects for a total of two hours.

Outdoor Adventurer.1: Learn about the Scout Basic Essentials.
Outdoor Adventurer.2: Determine what you will bring on an overnight campout — including a tent and sleeping bag/gear — and how you will carry your gear.
Outdoor Adventurer.3: Review the four points of Scouting America’s SAFE Checklist and how you will apply them on the campout.
Outdoor Adventurer.4: Locate the campsite where you will be camping on a map.
Outdoor Adventurer.5: With your patrol or a Scouting America troop, participate in a campout.
Outdoor Adventurer.6: Upon arrival at the campout determine where to set up your campsite: kitchen, eating area, tents, and firepit.  Help the patrol set up the patrol gear before setting up your own tent.
Outdoor Adventurer.7: Explain how to keep food safe and the kitchen area sanitary at the campsite.  Demonstrate your knowledge during the campout.
Outdoor Adventurer.8: After your campout, discuss with your patrol what went well and what you would do differently next time.   Include how you followed the Outdoor Code and Leave No Trace Principles for Kids.

Arrow of Light Elective Adventure.1: Choose and complete any Arrow of Light elective adventure

Arrow of Light Elective Adventure 2.1: Choose and complete any Arrow of Light elective adventure
